publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 80.31

seg.seg: The broad cloak (stain)ed (?) with blood she called incessantly with a hoarse voice full of love. 3. Thereupon prince Uttara while grasping [his] mother, the queen, by the chin
Mit heiserer(?) Stimme rief sie ihn voll Liebe ununterbrochen.
With a hoarse(?) voice she called him, full of love, incessantly.
speaks to her: “My dear mother! Do tell [my] dear father, he must not give me to those Rākṣasas!” Thereupon for love to the (prince) the king Araṇemi (broke) into a sweat all over his body
Dear mummy, tell dad that he mustn't give me to those rākṣasas!
due to the pain. ... having turned decrepit with soothing (?) word[s] (to the) prince Uttara (he speaks): “Darling! Humans those are, not
Yakṣas! Do not be afraid!” The Brahmins speak: “(You will not, oh gre)at king, revert from your own resolution?” Thereupon the king, after grasping with one hand
the prince Uttara [and] (with the other hand) the water (of gift), with a heavy [lit. swollen] heart surrenders the prince (and speaks to the Brahmins:) || (In) [the tune] taruṇadi(vākar ||)
“How can I give away (Uttara), [my] (god)like little son, who is hard [for me] to give away. I do not pay attention to own sorr(ow) ...
How can I give [away] Uttara, my dear son of divine appearance who is difficult to let go? I do not pay attention to my own sorrow … (cf 240)

... For this reason ... with (the kni)fe of ... I want to smash (?) into little pieces the false(hood) of the world (at large.” 1.) (Then after) the (ki)ng has (sur)rendered the prince to the Brahmins
he sits (sh)aking (with) pa(in). (Thereupon) drag(ging) the prince Uttara [away] by both arms .... the (Bra)hmins (went) out of the palace.
There, looking around helplessly ... Uttara speaks hoarsely (?) with his little tongue .... lamenting: “[My] father, lord, do
O Herr, Väterchen! Nimm mich doch von (diesen Rākṣasas) weg!
Oh lord, dear father! Do take me away from (these rākṣasas)!
take me away from (these Rākṣasas)! You are alive still; but now these will (de)vour me. When he had heard this, king Araṇemi
You are still alive, now that these eat me up. (cf 101; 315)
Dem König Araṇemi bebte seine Galle.
[Inside] king Araṇemi his gall quivered.
Als er dies gehört hatte, wurde König Araṇemi ohnmächtig [wtl. bebte dem König Araṇemi seine Galle], [und] fiel zu Boden.
When he had heard this, King Araṇemi fainted [lit. the bile of king Araṇemi quivered] [and] fell to the ground.
fainted [lit. his gall quivered] [and] fell to the ground. Thereupon a great voice of lament was heard. Thereupon now the Brahmins, threatening the prince
Da wurde eine große Klagestimme gehört.
Thereupon a great voice of lament was heard.

Uttara with harsh words, speak to him: “Go, go, son of a commoner! You have fallen into our hands and your father [you] will not (see [ever again])!” Meanwhile (walking step by step) the Brahmins thereupon ...
You have come into our hands and you can/will not see your father [anymore].

p.note: Continues , continued on . The translation follows 313-5.

The mother’s lament. King Araṇemi surrenders his son to the Brahmins, who lead him away in spite of his wailing and resistance. Lines a2-b4 overlap with . At line b4 the parallel text commences. This latter text shows some minor deviations from our text here.
Note the monophthong -o in snai-kärsto for snai-kärstau; the same monophthongized form is attested in b 1, which belongs to the same manuscript, and there it is also at the end of a sentence.

Most recently, 313 with fn. 66 favors the restoration of a PPt of Pt IV lalaupäṣṣusa from the root "to besmirch", but this, of course, remains uncertain, the more so since there is yet no other attestation of a kausativum from this root (although such a kausativum would be perfectly regular).

Thomas in 239 proposes to restore pletksa su no ("sinngemäß") at the beginning; the preterite of the verb plätk- "to flow, develop" makes indeed sense, but the damaged akṣara cannot belong to a sign with e-vowel.
Maybe in arañcä the virama stroke is simply missing by error; since the passage is not metrical, preservation of -ä is unlikely.
The Paris parallel a 3 seems to offer a sligtly different text. See the discussion there.
For the interpretation and translation of tāsau, see 358.
For the restoration see the parallel a 4.

In contrast to Sieg/Siegling—who identify the meter as 20|22|10|15—, 314 fn. 70 rather proposes 19|19|10|19 (7/7/5 and 5/5). This seems to be correct, since it fits the restoration that can be achieved now by a new reading of the parallel fragment b 1.

314 fn. 74 is right in refuting Sieg/Siegling's proposal to restore to (ṣañ ṣar)sa due to the "handschriftliche Befund", but he gives no alternative restoration. The remains of the preceeding akṣara speak in favor of (·)[ta]rsa, and this is now actually supported by the parallel b1, where [ṣṣ](·) [ś](·) (– –) [lyk](·)[śk](·) can be read; this can be restored to ṣṣe śas)tärsa ; lykaśke.
Due to new attestations from the root yärttā- “to drag”, the restoration yä(rt)t(amane) is the most likely, see 800.
The parallel b 4 has the obl.pl.masc. cenän from the demonstrative pronoun seṃ, which makes more sense with respect to its deixis as recognitional pronoun.
The direct speach of the Brahmins differs in a 4. At the end Sieg/Siegling restore i(ke-postäṃ ynemane).

list.item:
Continues [[THT 84]], continued on [[THT 86]]. The translation follows [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 313-5.

The mother’s lament. King Araṇemi surrenders his son to the Brahmins, who lead him away in spite of his wailing and resistance. Lines a2-b4 overlap with [[PK NS 355]]. At line b4 the parallel text [[THT 86]] commences. This latter text shows some minor deviations from our text here.

a1 Most recently, [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 313 with fn. 66 favors the restoration of a PPt of Pt IV lalaupäṣṣusa from the root [[lupā- (Gv.)]] "to besmirch", but this, of course, remains uncertain, the more so since there is yet no other attestation of a kausativum from this root (although such a kausativum would be perfectly regular).

a3 Thomas in [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 239 proposes to restore pletksa su no ("sinngemäß") at the beginning; the preterite of the verb plätk- "to flow, develop" makes indeed sense, but the damaged akṣara cannot belong to a sign with e-vowel.

a5 The Paris parallel [[PK NS 355]] a 3 seems to offer a sligtly different text. See the discussion there.

a6 For the restoration see the parallel [[PK NS 355]] a 4.

a6ff. In contrast to Sieg/Siegling—who identify the meter as 20|22|10|15—, [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 314 fn. 70 rather proposes 19|19|10|19 (7/7/5 and 5/5). This seems to be correct, since it fits the restoration that can be achieved now by a new reading of the parallel fragment [[PK NS 355]] b 1.

b1 [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 314 fn. 74 is right in refuting Sieg/Siegling's proposal to restore to (ṣañ ṣar)sa due to the "handschriftliche Befund", but he gives no alternative restoration. The remains of the preceeding akṣara speak in favor of (·)[ta]rsa, and this is now actually supported by the parallel [[PK NS 355]] b1, where [ṣṣ](·) [ś](·) (– –) [lyk](·)[śk](·) can be read; this can be restored to ṣṣe śas)tärsa ; lykaśke.

b2 Due to new attestations from the root yärttā- “to drag”, the restoration yä(rt)t(amane) is the most likely, see [[Malzahn 2010]]: 800.

b4 The parallel [[PK NS 355]] b 4 has the obl.pl.masc. cenän from the demonstrative pronoun seṃ, which makes more sense with respect to its deixis as recognitional pronoun.

b6 The direct speach of the Brahmins differs in [[THT 86]] a 4. At the end Sieg/Siegling restore i(ke-postäṃ ynemane).

a1 Note the monophthong -o in snai-kärsto for snai-kärstau; the same monophthongized form is attested in [[THT 88]] b 1, which belongs to the same manuscript, and there it is also at the end of a sentence.

a5 Maybe in arañcä the virama stroke is simply missing by error; since the passage is not metrical, preservation of -ä is unlikely.

a6 For the interpretation and translation of tāsau, see [[Peyrot 2010]]: 358.

a1 ṣṣusa kampāl aurcce sā_u ysārasa • weksa sr(·)kañce kwoy_t_ar-ne taṅsa snai _k_arsto 3 || tumeṃ uttare [m](···)[ṣ]k(·) wcukaisa mā_t_a_r\ lāntso eṅku a2 we_ṣ_an-neścä ṣarya ammakki poññ āppai mā ñiś cempaṃt_s\• rakṣatsents ai_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ || tane araṇemiñ lānte – (–) nne eṅ_k_altsa po kektseñmeṃ _l_a a3 kleñä\ syel[m]e – (– – –) ○ ylāre kaklautk[au _t_a]rraskemane rekisa uttareṃ m(···)[ṣ](k)eṃ (– –) larekka śāmna caim_p\• skente mā [ya] a4 kṣī mā twe prās[k·] (– – – –) ○ ṇi weskeṃ (– – – –) ccu walo ṣañ pratinmeṃ [kl]au (– – – –) || tumeṃ walo ṣeme ṣarsa u(–) a5 reṃ mñcuṣkeṃ [e] (– – – – – ·)[o]rṣ(ṣ)e [w](a)r eṅku arañc[ä] st(· –)ske[ma]ne mñcuṣkeṃ āy[o] (– – – – – –) – – – || taruṇadi (– – – –) a6 _m_akte ai·(·)au – – – – – – – – – – r(·)e amāskai rilye • mā ṣ keś (·)āsau ṣañ la /// b1 te ṣarmtsa (– – – – – – – – – – ·)[_t_a]rsa lykaśke tāksoy_m\ śai[ṣ]ṣ(·)ntse mithy[a] (– – – – – – –) [lo] mñcuṣkeṃ brāhmaṇeṃ[ts](· – – –) b2 wamane l[a] (– – – – – – – – ·)[r](·)hmaṇi uttareṃ mñ(··)ṣkeṃ [a]ntapi pokainesa y[ä](·)t(· – – – – – – –) – kercīyeṃnmeṃ [pa]rna (– –) b3 tane uttare (– – – –) ○ lkāskemane (– – ··)· naṃ t_r_antācce _k_antwāśkesa (– – – – –) mane we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ saswa appa[kk](· –) b4 pi psāmpar ñ[iś(ä)\] (– –)[kṣ](·)○tsenmeṃ lok[e] ykāk tv(·) śāmane nes_tä\ ñake ṅke c[ai] ñ(·)ś _p_a(– ·)[u]waṃ || te keklyaurmeṃ araṇemiñ lā b5 nte pit maiwāte-ne k(·)tsa klāya • tane orottsa kwasalñeṣṣa weśeñña klyauṣāte || tane ñake brā[h](··)ṇi uttareṃ _m__añcuṣkeṃ ścirona rekauna b6 sa _s_k_arrāmane weskeṃ-ne paṣ pa_ṣ\ _k_arpīyet_s\ soṃśka we_s_añ\ ñake ṣarnene kekamu nes_t\ mā ṣ pāt_r_a (–)lle nes_t\ || tumeṃ brāhmaṇi tott i

a1 The broad cloak (stain)ed (?) with blood she called incessantly with a hoarse voice full of love. 3. Thereupon prince Uttara while grasping [his] mother, the queen, by the chin a2 speaks to her: “My dear mother! Do tell [my] dear father, he must not give me to those Rākṣasas!” Thereupon for love to the (prince) the king Araṇemi (broke) into a sweat all over his body a3 due to the pain. ... having turned decrepit with soothing (?) word[s] (to the) prince Uttara (he speaks): “Darling! Humans those are, not a4 Yakṣas! Do not be afraid!” The Brahmins speak: “(You will not, oh gre)at king, revert from your own resolution?” Thereupon the king, after grasping with one hand a5 the prince Uttara [and] (with the other hand) the water (of gift), with a heavy [lit. swollen] heart surrenders the prince (and speaks to the Brahmins:) || (In) [the tune] taruṇadi(vākar ||) a6 “How can I give away (Uttara), [my] (god)like little son, who is hard [for me] to give away. I do not pay attention to own sorr(ow) ... b1 ... For this reason ... with (the kni)fe of ... I want to smash (?) into little pieces the false(hood) of the world (at large.” 1.) (Then after) the (ki)ng has (sur)rendered the prince to the Brahmins b2 he sits (sh)aking (with) pa(in). (Thereupon) drag(ging) the prince Uttara [away] by both arms .... the (Bra)hmins (went) out of the palace. b3 There, looking around helplessly ... Uttara speaks hoarsely (?) with his little tongue .... lamenting: “[My] father, lord, do b4 take me away from (these Rākṣasas)! You are alive still; but now these will (de)vour me. When he had heard this, king Araṇemi b5 fainted [lit. his gall quivered] [and] fell to the ground. Thereupon a great voice of lament was heard. Thereupon now the Brahmins, threatening the prince b6 Uttara with harsh words, speak to him: “Go, go, son of a commoner! You have fallen into our hands and your father [you] will not (see [ever again])!” Meanwhile (walking step by step) the Brahmins thereupon ...

a1 ṣṣusa ; kampāl aurcce sā_u , ysārasa • #3c weksa sr(a)kañce ; kwoytär-ne taṅksa|taṅsa , snai kärstau|kärsto 3 || #3d tumeṃ uttare m(ñcu)ṣk(e) wcukaisa mātär lāntso eṅku a2 weṣṣäṃ-neśc|weṣän-neścä ṣarya ammakki poñ|poññ āppai mā ñiś cempaṃts rākṣatseṃts|rakṣatsents aiṣṣäṃ || tane araṇemiñ lānte (mñcuṣke)nne eṅkältsa po kektseñmeṃ läkleñ|lä|kleñ a3 syelme – (– pletksa) ylāre kaklautkau tärraskemane rekisa uttareṃ m(ñcu)ṣ(k)eṃ(śc weṣṣäṃ) larekka śāmna caimp skente mā yakṣī|ya|kṣī a4 mā twe prāskat_(Prs.)|prāsk(at || brāhma)ṇi weskeṃ (mapi oro)ccu walo ṣañ pratinmeṃ klau(tkalle nest) || tumeṃ walo ṣeme ṣarsa uttareṃ|u(tta)|reṃ a5 mñcuṣkeṃ e(ṅku wace ṣarsa āy)orṣ(ṣ)e w(a)r eṅku arañc|arañcä st(aukkä)skemane mñcuṣkeṃ āyo(rmeṃ brāhmaṇeṃśc weṣṣäṃ) || taruṇadi(vākarne ||) a6 # mäkte ai(sk)au , (uttareṃ ; ñäkte-yokäṃ , s_äsuwe)r(śk)e«ṃ» ; amāskai rilye • #1a mā ṣ keś (t)āsau , ṣañ la(kle) ; /// %12 #1b %11 b1 , te ṣarmtsa ; (– – – – – #1c – – – ṣṣe , śas)tärsa ; lykaśke tāksoym , śaiṣṣ(e)ntse ; mithya(dṛṣṭi po 1 || #1d tumeṃ wa)lo mñcuṣkeṃ brāhmaṇeṃts (āyormeṃ) miwamane|(mi)|wamane b2 la(klene ṣamäṃ || tumeṃ b)r(ā)hmaṇi uttareṃ mñ(cu)ṣkeṃ antapi pokainesa yä(rt)t(amane – – – – –) – kercciyeṃmeṃ|kercīyeṃnmeṃ parna (lateṃ) b3 tane uttare (enersäṅk) lkāskemane (– –) (··)·naṃ träntācce käntwāśkesa (– – – pälwā)mane weṣṣäṃ saswa appakk(a) mapi|(ma)|pi b4 psāmpar ñiś (ceṃ rā)kṣ(a)tsenmeṃ lauke|loke ykāk twe|tv(e) śāmane nest ñake ṅke cai ñ(i)ś pä(st) śuwaṃ_(Sub.Pl.)|(ś)uwaṃ || te keklyau«ṣo»rmeṃ araṇemiñ lānte|lā|nte b5 pit maiwāte-ne kentsa|k(eṃ)tsa klāya • tane orotstsa|orottsa kwasalñeṣṣa weśeñña klyauṣāte || tane ñake brāh(ma)ṇi uttareṃ mñcuṣkeṃ|m_äñcuṣkeṃ ścirona rekaunasa|rekauna|sa b6 skärrāmane weskeṃ-ne paṣ paṣ kärpīye«ṃ»ts soṃśka wesäñ ñake ṣarnene kekamu nest mā ṣ pātär|pāträ (lkā)lle nest || tumeṃ brāhmaṇi tot|tott ike-postäṃ|i|(ke-postäṃ)

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a2 also PK NS 355 a1 Dear mummy, tell dad that he mustn't give me to those rākṣasas! 305
a6 How can I give [away] Uttara, my dear son of divine appearance who is difficult to let go? I do not pay attention to my own sorrow … (cf [[Couvreur 1964]]: 240) 431
b4 You are still alive, now that these eat me up. (cf [[Couvreur 1954c]]: 101; [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 315) 374
b6 You have come into our hands and you can/will not see your father [anymore]. 341

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1 Mit heiserer(?) Stimme rief sie ihn voll Liebe ununterbrochen. 95
b3-4 O Herr, Väterchen! Nimm mich doch von (diesen Rākṣasas) weg! 409
b4-5 Dem König Araṇemi bebte seine Galle. 209, fn. 2
b4-5 Als er dies gehört hatte, wurde König Araṇemi ohnmächtig [wtl. bebte dem König Araṇemi seine Galle], [und] fiel zu Boden. 122
b5 Da wurde eine große Klagestimme gehört. 81, 217
